Your full name: ARNOLD DAUK

Present Address: ANNAHEIM, SASK.

Pioneer Address: Sand

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1904

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaires.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About thirty.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? Not many, mostly working with families.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Occasionally.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Mostly on a Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? In both ways.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Mostly in the afternoon or evening.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) People were expected to have lunch when visiting.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Usually coffee and light lunch.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Occasionally.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. For putting up first log houses, later for making quilts and sewing for church friends.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Some dances in homes among neighbors.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. After people could go with cars.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Occasionally had dance at different places.

PLAIDERS RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's houses? How many were married couples' houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Weekly, monthly, occasionally.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Weekly, on Saturdays.

4. Were you often invited to other houses, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Occasionally.

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually in the afternoon or evening.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make polite?" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Usually coffee and light lunch.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "wee" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Occasionally.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates, if possible, telling what the "wees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Occasionally, but always at different times.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? Lumber How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Built by St. Arnold parish

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Built in the village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

Hall is used for nearly all social functions

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?
